Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Modeling and Inference of Gene Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The environment within living cells is incredibly noisy with biochemical species randomly bumping and reacting with each other. This inherent probabilistic nature along with low population counts of cellular species creates considerable stochastic fluctuations in protein copy numbers over time inside individual cells. Increasing evidence suggests that this stochastic dynamics plays important functional roles within cells. Moreover, many diseased states have been attributed to elevated noise levels in specific proteins. Stochastic analysis of biochemical processes relies heavily on Monte Carlo simulation techniques that come at a significant computational cost. In addition, these techniques do not provide closed-form solutions that enable a systematic understanding of how stochastic variability is regulated in these systems. This project will overcome these challenges by developing computationally tractable methodologies based on moment closure schemes for studying stochastic dynamics of gene regulatory networks. Various analytical approximations that relate statistical properties of the system to biologically relevant parameters will be investigated. Far from being a hindrance, signatures of protein noise levels can be informative of the underlying gene network topology. This project will build mathematical techniques that harness quantitative measurements of stochasticity in protein levels for inferring regulatory interactions between genes and proteins.

Biological data is being collected at a rapid rate and innovative methods for analyzing data are critically needed. Advances in experimental techniques allow measurements of fluctuations in protein levels in individual cells, which carry useful information to probe interactions between genes and proteins. In this project, tools exploiting statistical properties of these fluctuations to characterize cellular processes will be developed and will be made available for the broad scientific community to use. Stochastic variability in protein levels has been implicated in bacterial antibiotic resistance, mutation-independent selection of tumors and driving pathogenic human viruses, e.g., HIV, into a drug-resistant dormant state. This research will improve the characterizations of gene networks underlying these disease systems and thus this research will have a broader impact on medicine. Many of the results of this project will be incorporated into various courses offered across different departments providing interdisciplinary training and research experience to students at the interface of mathematical and biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The environment within living cells is incredibly noisy with biochemical species randomly bumping and reacting with each other. This inherent probabilistic nature along with low population counts of cellular species creates considerable stochastic fluctuations in protein copy numbers over time inside individual cells. How biochemical processes perform biological function with fidelity in spite of stochasticity is an intriguing fundamental problem. Increasing evidence suggests that these random fluctuations play important functional roles, from determining cell fate in single cells to allowing differential cellular response to the same stimuli. Moreover, many diseased states have been attributed to elevated noise levels in specific proteins. To better understand how noise at molecular level affects biological function and phenotype, the project aimed to develop analytical/computational methods for studying stochastic dynamics of complex networks of interconnected gene and proteins.

Stochastic analysis of biochemical processes relies heavily on Monte Carlo simulation techniques that come at a significant computational cost. Addressing this challenge, the project developed novel closure schemes that provide rapid and reliable prediction of statistical moments for the number of molecules of different species involved in a given arbitrary set of biochemical reactions. Moreover, mathematical methods based on semidefinite programming were built that provide precise errors bounds between the predicted and the actual moments dynamics. Interestingly, the project uncovered a class of nonlinear biochemical systems for which moment dynamics can be obtained exactly by solving a system of differential equations, without needing any closure-based approximations. These tools were used to address a variety of fundamental problems in noise biology, such as, using feedback control to buffer noise in the expression of genes, quantifying the effects of nonspecific protein binding on the magnitude/timescale of fluctuations in their copy numbers, and inferring gene expression parameters from measured single-cell data on protein/mRNA levels.

The project has lead to mentoring of graduate, undergraduate and high school students at the intersection applied mathematics, biology and systems engineering. REU supplements resulted in 5 peer-reviewed papers with undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented minority backgrounds. As part of the project, a new course “Computational Systems Biology” was developed and taught. Course enrollment was quite impressive: approximately 40 students from different majors (Engineering, Math, Physics, Biology, Computer Science). Research projects are assigned to groups of 2-4 students with complimentary math skills and knowledge in life sciences. This format proved very successful, as many class projects resulted in peer-reviewed publications. Several summer internships were organized for high school students introducing them to basic tools for mathematical modeling of biological systems.  Finally, the project catalyzed experimental collaborations with several experimental groups leading to joint papers in high-impact journals, such as, Nature and Molecular Cell.
